title: 106_hr5448
content: The Act is titled the "New Economy Workforce Act" and prioritizes education for certain family-sponsored immigrants. Section 203(e)(1) of the Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to allow immigrant visas for aliens without a bachelor's degree or high school diploma if no qualified individual with higher education is available. The Immigration and Nationality Act allows immigrant visas for aliens without a bachelor's degree or high school diploma if no qualified individual with higher education is available. The definition of educational status includes foreign degrees equivalent to a bachelor's degree and completion of a 12-year course of study. SEC. 3 amends the Immigration and Nationality Act to require diversity immigrants to have a bachelor's degree or higher. SEC. 4 outlines the Secretary of State's obligations regarding foreign degree equivalence and verification of educational credentials. Section 203 of the Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to require the Secretary of State to determine the equivalence of foreign degrees or courses of study for aliens. This includes verifying the authenticity of any foreign educational credentials provided by the alien. The Secretary of State, in consultation with the Attorney General and the Secretary of Education, will promulgate regulations within 90 days of the enactment of the Act regarding the allocation of immigrant visas and determinations with respect to foreign degrees under section 203 of the Immigration and Nationality Act. The Secretary of State will charge a processing and verification fee to recover costs for section 203(h). A separate account called the "Foreign Degree Equivalence Account" will receive all collected fees. The funds will be available for the Secretary of State to use for section 203(h) activities. Other regulations will be established within 90 days of the Act's enactment. The Attorney General, in consultation with the Secretary of State and the Secretary of Education, will promulgate regulations within 90 days of the Act's enactment. Revised forms will be made available by the Attorney General and the Secretary of State with instructions on establishing an alien's educational attainment level. The amendments made by this Act will apply to immigrant visas under the Immigration and Nationality Act, with specific effective dates mentioned.
